questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about mucinous cystadenoma of the pancreas?

choices.text: It is lined by columnar epithelium
Identified histologically by the presence of ovarian-like stroma

questions.solution:
Mucinous cystadenoma of the pancreas is a premalignant condition.

Mucinous cystadenoma or mucinous cystic neoplasm (MCN) is a benign tumor of the pancreas with high risk of malignancy. They are commonly seen in perimenopausal women, and about two-thirds are located in the body or tail of the pancreas.

MCNs are mostly incidental findings. When symptoms are present, they are usually nonspecific and include upper abdominal discomfort, early satiety, or weight loss.

The cysts are lined by tall columnar epithelium. MCN's contain mucin-producing epithelium and are identified histologically by the presence of mucin-rich cells and ovarian-like stroma. Staining for estrogen and progesterone is positive in most cases.

Malignant transformation of MCN is common with large tumors and old patients. This is due to a stepwise accumulation of mutations (K-ras, p53).

WHO classification of primary tumors of the pancreas
Benign
  • Mucinous cystadenoma
  • Serous cystadenoma
  • Intraductal papillary mucinous adenoma
  • Mature teratoma
Borderline
  • Mucinous cystic tumor with moderate dysplasia
  • Intraductal papillary mucinous tumor with moderate dysplasia
  • Solid pseudopapillary tumor
Malignant
  • Ductal adenocarcinoma
  • Serous/mucinous cystadenocarcinoma
  • Intraductal mucinous papillary tumor

questions.text: A patient with a pancreatic neoplasm undergoes cyst fluid aspiration. The aspirated fluid stains positive for mucin and shows elevated levels of amylase and CEA. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Positive mucin staining, elevated carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), and elevated amylase levels are seen in cases of intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN).

Cyst fluid analysis of various pancreatic cystic neoplasms:

Characteristics Serous cystic neoplasm (SCN) Mucinous cystic neoplasm (MCN) Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN)
Cytology

Scant glycogen-rich cells, with positive periodic acid–Schiff stain

Tall, columnar, mucin-containing cells
Mucin stain Negative Positive Positive
Amylase Low Low High
CEA Low High High

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is being evaluated for recurrent attacks of pancreatitis. An ERCP is done and it shows the presence of a fish-mouth sign at the ampulla of Vater. Which of the following statements is true about his condition?

choices.text: It is more common in males
It only involves the main pancreatic duct
Head of pancreas is most common site of the neoplasm

questions.solution:
A fish mouth sign at the ampulla of Vater during ERCP is indicative of intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN). It is most commonly seen in the head of the pancreas.

The intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm can be diagnosed with the following findings (Ohashi triad) during endoscopy:

  • Bulging ampulla of Vater (fish-mouth sign)
  • Dilated pancreatic duct
  • Mucin secretion from the opening

Equal distribution is seen between males and females in IPMN. Patients are usually in their seventh or eighth decade of life and present with abdominal pain or recurrent pancreatitis. This is caused by the obstruction of the pancreatic duct by thick mucin. Some patients have symptoms secondary to pancreatic insufficiencies like steatorrhea, diabetes, and weight loss.

IMPNs are of three types:

  • Branch-duct IPMN (BD-IPMN) - affects only the small side branches. It is less frequently associated with malignancy.
  • Main duct IPMN (MD-IPMN) - Affects the main pancreatic duct. Malignant transformation is commonly seen.
  • Mixed-type IPMN - side-branch IPMNs that extend into the main duct

questions.text: A 60-year-old man was incidentally found to have a pancreatic lesion on a USG. On further evaluation, a CT scan revealed the presence of a multicystic, lobulated mass in the pancreatic head, suggestive of serous cystadenoma. He is currently asymptomatic. What will be the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Endoscopic ultrasound-guided FNA (EUS-FNA) will be the next step in the management of this patient.

Serous cystadenomas are essentially benign tumors without malignant potential. Serous cystadenocarcinoma has been reported very rarely (<1%). Therefore, malignant potential should not be a consideration for surgical resection. Surgical resection is done only for symptomatic patients.

In asymptomatic patients, conservative management is adopted. However, it is important to confirm the diagnosis using EUS-FNA. It yields a non-viscous fluid with low CEA and amylase levels.

questions.text: What is the initiating event in the oncogenesis of pancreatic cancers?
questions.solution:
The activation of the K-ras 2 oncogene is the initiating event in the oncogenesis of pancreatic cancers. It is activated in more than 95% of pan­creatic cancers.

Pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN) develops into pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) in a sequential pathway. A number of tumor suppressor genes and oncogenes play a significant role in the pathogenesis of PDAC. They include:

  • K-ras 2
  • PDX1
  • CDKN2A/p16
  • p53
  • DPC4 (SMAD4)

questions.text:
Which of the following are not risk factors for the development of pancreatic cancer?
  1. History of acute pancreatitis
  2. Long-standing diabetes mellitus
  3. BRCA2 mutation
  4. Female gender
  5. Cigarette smoking
questions.solution:
An history of acute pancreatitis and female gender are not risk factors for the development of pancreatic cancer.

Risk factors for pancreatic cancer:

  • Demographic factors:
    • Age (peak incidence, 65–75 years)
    • Male gender
    • Black ethnicity
  • Cigarette smoking
  • Genetic factors and medical conditions
  • Family history:
    • Two first-degree relatives with pancreas cancer
    • Germline BRCA2 mutations in some rare high-risk families
  • Hereditary pancreatitis
  • Chronic pancreatitis
  • Lynch syndrome
  • Ataxia telangiectasia
  • Peutz–Jeghers syndrome
  • Familial breast-ovarian cancer syndrome
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis 
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Obesity

questions.text: What is the most common type of pancreatic malignancy?
questions.solution:
Ductal adenocarcinoma is the most common type of pancreatic cancer.

Types of exocrine pancreatic cancer:

  • Ductal adenocarcinoma (85%)
  • Adenosquamous carcinoma
  • Acinar cell carcinoma

Endocrine cancer of the pancreas is rare. They account for only 5% of clinically detected pancreatic tumours.

questions.text: What is the most common site for pancreatic carcinoma?
questions.solution: Pancreatic carcinomas arise most commonly from the head of the gland.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the presentation of patients with pancreatic carcinoma?

choices.text: Release of platelet aggregating factors cause migratory thrombophlebitis
Abdominal pain is the most common presentation
Courvoisier's law implicates possible cancer of the head of the pancreas
Tumors of the body present at an advanced unresectable stage

questions.solution:
Jaundice is the most common presentation of carcinoma of the head of the pancreas. It is secondary to obstruction of the distal bile duct.

Clinical features of pancreatic cancers:

  • Jaundice (most common)
  • Nausea
  • Epigastric discomfort
  • Pruritus, dark urine, pale stools
  • Steatorrhea
  • Anorexia
  • Weight loss
  • Back pain - indicates retroperitoneal infiltration

On examination, the patient can have:

  • Palpable abdominal mass
  • Ascites
  • Supraclavicular lymphnodes
  • Migratory superficial thrombophlebitis (Trousseau’s sign of malignancy) - due to release of platelet aggregating factors from the tumor
  • Secondaries in the rectovesical pouch (Blumer’s shelf)
  • A palpable, non-tender gall bladder

Courvoisier's law states that in the presence of a painless, palpable, enlarged gallbladder and mild jaundice, the cause is unlikely to be gallstones. This sign implicates possible cancer of the head of the pancreas.

Tumors of the body and tail of the gland often grow silently and present at an advanced unresectable stage.

Image showing migratory superficial thrombophlebitis (Trousseau’s sign of malignancy):

 

Note: Trousseau's sign is also seen in hypocalcemia. It indicates carpopedal spasm (finger and wrist spasm) after inflation of a blood pressure cuff for several minutes when the brachial artery is occluded.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma?

choices.text: It is associated with desmoplastic changes, with scattering of neoplastic glands
Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas causes obstruction of both the pancreatic and biliary ducts

questions.solution:
Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinomas situated in the body of the pancreas are usually larger.

Pancreatic adenocarcinomas are solid, slow-growing tumors, characterized by neoplastic tubular glands within a markedly desmoplastic fibrous stroma. They infiltrate locally, typically along nerve sheaths, along lymphatics, and into blood vessels.

Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas causes obstruction of both the pancreatic and biliary ducts.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic pancreatitis presents with jaundice, severe itching, and weight loss. A smooth, globular mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. You suspect pancreatic cancer. What will be the imaging modality of choice for the evaluation of the tumor?
questions.solution:
Multidetector computed tomography (CT) is the imaging modality of choice for the evalua­tion of pancreatic tumors. It allows an accurate determination of the level of biliary obstruction, the relationship of the tumor to the blood vessels, and the presence of regional or metastatic disease.

For a detailed assessment of the luminal pancreato-biliary anatomy, MRCP should be considered. 

ERCP is reserved for cases requiring therapeutic or palliative intervention. It helps to perform a biopsy and to relieve obstruction by biliary stenting. The invasiveness of ERCP increases the rate of wound infection. Hence, it is not suitable for patients who will be undergoing surgery.

F-fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (FDG-PET) has the ability to differentiate between benign and malignant pancreas tumors. However, false-positive results are seen in FDG-PET. The benefits of FDG-PET over CT scans are yet to be determined.

questions.text: Which of the following is a radiological sign that is not seen in patients with adenocarcinoma of the pancreas?

choices.text: Narrowing of C-loop of the duodenum

questions.solution:
Widening of the C-loop of the duodenum is a barium meal finding seen in the adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.

Radiological features of adenocarcinoma pancreas:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) findings:

  • Scrambled egg appearance
  • Double duct appearance

Barium meal findings:

  • Inverse 3 sign
  • Rose thorning of 2nd part of the duodenum
  • Widened duodenal C-loop

questions.text: The best method to obtain tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma is:

choices.text: Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound

questions.solution:
Transgastric or transduodenal FNAC or trucut biopsy performed under endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) guidance is the best method to obtain tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma. This is because it avoids the spillage of tumor cells into the peritoneal cavity. 

Endoscopic ultrasonography with a fine needle aspiration (EUS-FNA) is done if CT has failed to demonstrate a tumor. When a tissue diagnosis is required prior to surgery to distinguish between inflammation and neoplasia, EUS-FNA is helpful.

Diagnostic laparoscopy prior to resection can spare an unnecessary laparotomy by identifying small peritoneal and liver metastases.

Percutaneous transperitoneal biopsy of potentially resectable pancreatic tumors is avoided.

questions.text: Which is the most reliable tumor marker for the pre-treatment evaluation of a patient with pancreatic adenocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Carbohydrate antigen (CA) 19-9 is the most reliable tumor marker for pretreatment evaluation and post-treatment surveillance of pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

Other tumor markers for pancreatic carcinoma are carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) and α-fetoprotein.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. In order to diagnose a resectability status, a CECT abdomen is performed. Which of the following features will indicate an unresectable tumor?

choices.text: Stage II cancer on AJCC staging criteria
Short segment occlusion of superior mesenteric vein

questions.solution:
Encasement of the celiac artery ( i.e >180° or >50% of the vessel circumference involvement) indicates surgical inoperability and is therefore considered to be non-resectable.

Varadhachary- Katz criteria for resectability of pancreatic cancer:

Criteria

Resectable

(if all are satisfied)

Borderline resectable

(if any one is satisfied)

Unresectable

(if any one is satisfied)
AJCC stage I/II III III
SMA Not affected Abutment Encasement
Celiac axis Not affected Abutment Encasement
CHA Not affected Abutment Encasement

Note: Any evidence of peritoneal seeding, malignant ascites, or distant metastasis also indicates an unresectable tumor.

SMA: superior mesenteric artery, CHA: common hepatic artery, SMV-PV: superior mesenteric vein-portal vein confluence

Definitions:

  • Abutment means ≤180° or ≤50% of the vessel circumference involvement; 
  • Encasement means >180° or >50% of the vessel circumference  involvement

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of jaundice, clay-colored stools, and pruritis. After detailed radiological and pathological investigations, a 2 cm adenocarcinoma is found at the head of the pancreas. There is no spread to the adjacent structures. What is the preferred surgical management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Since there is no involvement of adjacent structures, the preferred surgical management in this patient is pylorus-preserving pancreatoduodenectomy (PPPD), also known as Longmire–Traverso procedure.

Pylorus-preserving pancreatoduodenectomy (PPPD) involves the removal of:

  • Duodenum 
  • Pancreatic head
  • The distal part of the bile duct

The original pancreatoduodenectomy, as proposed by Whipple, included resection of the gastric antrum.

Preserving the antrum and the pylorus results in a better physiological outcome, with no difference in survival or recurrence rates. Hence PPPD is preferred.

For tumors of the body and tail, distal pancreatectomy is the preferred surgical management.

Duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection (Beger's procedure) and Puestow's procedure (resection of tail followed by longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy) are management options for chronic pancreatitis.

questions.text:
You assist in performing a Whipple procedure in a patient with carcinoma of the pancreas. All of the following structures will be resected in this surgery, except:
  1. Gallbladder
  2. Common bile duct
  3. Spleen
  4. Proximal jejunum
  5. Tail of the pancreas
questions.solution:
Whipple procedure does not involve the removal of the spleen and tail of the pancreas.

The Whipple procedure is a complex surgery done for carcinomas involving the head of the pancreas. It is done only in cases when:

  • The entire duodenum has to be removed e.g. in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)
  • Tumor encroaches in the first part of the duodenum, or stomach
  • A clear resection margin is not achieved by pylorus preserving pancreatoduodectomy

The following structures are removed during Whipple’s procedure:

  • Distal stomach
  • Duodenum
  • Proximal jejunum
  • Head of the pancreas
  • Gallbladder
  • Common bile duct (CBD)
  • Regional lymphatics

questions.text: During the reconstruction of the Whipple procedure, all of the following anastomoses will be done by a surgeon except:
questions.solution:
Ileojejunostomy will not be done during the reconstruction of the Whipple procedure.

The reconstruction following Whipple’s procedure or pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy involves anastomosis in the following order:

Pancreati­cojejunostomy

              ↓

Choledochojejunostomy

              ↓

Gastrojejunostomy

This is controversial since there is a difference in the reconstruction procedures mentioned in standard textbooks:

Bailey and Love, 27th edition (Pg no: 1236) - Pancreaticojejunostomy + choledechojejunostomy + duodenojejunostomy 

Schwatrz, 11th edition (Pg no: 1493) - Pancreaticojejunostomy + choledechojejunostomy + gastrojejunostomy/duodenojejunostomy

Sabiston, 20th edition (Pg no: 1546) - Pancreaticojejunostomy + hepaticojejunostomy + duodenojejunostomy

questions.text: During the Whipple procedure, a surgeon performs the Kocher maneuver to access the retroperitoneum. This maneuver involves:

choices.text: Mobilization of second part of duodenum

questions.solution:
The Kocher maneuver involves the mobilization of the second part of the duodenum. It allows exposure of the retroperitoneal fat and the inferior vena cava (IVC).

Another maneuver that is used to access the retroperitoneum is the Cattel Braasch maneuver. It involves the mobilization of the ascending colon.

Other Kocher's in medicine:

  • Kocher's technique is used for the reduction of anterior shoulder dislocation. It involves four steps:
    Traction → External Rotation → Adduction → Medial Rotation (TEAM)
  • During thyroid palpation, Kocher's method is done to demonstrate the pressure effect of the thyroid gland on the trachea or larynx. Lateral compression will result in stridor.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding complications of the Whipple procedure?

choices.text: Delayed gastric emptying is characterized by the need for prolonged nasogastric decompression
Any drainage output on or after postoperative day 3, with amylase >3 times normal value indicates pancreatic fistula
Biliary leakage is the most common complication

questions.solution:
Delayed gastric emptying is the most common complication following the Whipple procedure, not biliary leakage.

Delayed gastric emptying is characterized by the need for prolonged nasogastric decompression or the inability to tolerate oral intake. 

Most pancreatic fistulas are controlled by drainage catheters placed at the time of surgery. A pancreatic leak or pancreatic fistula is defined as the output via an intraoperatively placed drain (or percutaneous drain) of any measurable volume on or after postoperative day 3, with amylase >3 times the normal value. 

Other complications of the Whipple procedure include:

  • Wound infection
  • Intra-abdominal abscess
  • Cardiac events
  • Bile leak
  • Overall reoperation
  • Exocrine insufficiency
  • Endocrine insufficiency

questions.text: What is the most common cause of death in patients following pancreaticoduodenectomy?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of death following pancreaticoduodenectomy is sepsis due to anastomotic leakage.

Anastomotic leakage is responsible for 33–88 % of postoperative deaths after pancreaticoduodenectomy. Only about 5–16 % of patients develop post-surgical bleeding complications.

questions.text: A patient was found to have a 3 cm adenocarcinoma of the body of the pancreas invading into the superior mesenteric artery. All of the following chemotherapeutic agents can be utilized for the management of this patient except:
questions.solution:
MVAC regimen (methotrexate, vinblastine, adriamycin, and cisplatin) is not used in the management of this patient. MVAC regimen is used in advanced bladder carcinoma.

Chemotherapy in pancreatic cancer is indicated in patients with unresectable tumours and lymph node metastasis. Agents used in chemotherapy are:

  • Gemcitabine
  • Gemcitabine with capecitabine
  • Albumin bound paclitaxel (nab-paclitaxel)
  • FOLFIRINOX - a combination of fluorouracil, irinotecan, oxaliplatin, and leucovorin

However, there is only a 2–5 months increase in median survival with these regimens. No long-term cure is seen with chemotherapy or radiotherapy for pancreatic carcinomas.
